awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGRP - Adapting to a Harsh Environment:  Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi, Drought Stress and Plasticity of Plant Architecture for a Beneficial Outcome
awd_abstract_narration:
To meet the food and nutritional demands of an ever-growing population, food production must increase despite declines in arable land and limitations in key plant nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorous (Pi), increased soil salinity, and predicted increases in the frequency of droughts. Meeting future food needs is one of the greatest challenges facing the world today, and can be addressed through crop improvement and soil management. Little is known of how plants integrate beneficial interactions with soil microbes and environmental limitations (i.e., insufficient water) to modulate their growth. This project is developing new technologies for studying the interaction between plants and microbes, focusing on how rice and tomato interact with beneficial fungi under varied irrigation conditions. The results will make it possible to improve plant-microbe interactions so that plants can better sustain vital functions under stressful conditions. The technologies will be broadly applicable to other aspects of plant-environmental interactions and to other multicellular organisms. In addition, the project is introducing students in local schools to topics in plant genetics that highlight the importance of beneficial organisms. 

This project seeks to identify key gene regulatory, signaling, and response networks that underlie beneficial plasticity in plant root development and shoot meristem activity mediated by the symbiosis with Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi (AMF), particularly under water deficit conditions. The project assesses how AMF influences root architecture and meristematic development under low water availability. The specific aims are to (1) Develop inducible i-INTACT and i-TRAP to capture epigenome to translatome dynamics in the subset of cells responding to distinct AMF elicitors or developing arbuscules; (2) Initiate a high-resolution survey of AMF and water deficit interactions from the organ to the cellular level in the greenhouse; and (3) Pursue education and broader impact activities. This includes (i) prompt dissemination of genetic material, genomic data, protocols, software, and workshop materials; (ii) annual instruction of methods in courses, workshops and undergraduate teaching labs; and (iii) hands-on training of undergraduate and high school students in plant genomics research. Mentoring is tailored to each institution's community, targeting underrepresented groups. The project also develops teaching materials to enhance the 3rd grade Next Generation Science Standard curricula through instruction on plant parts at the microscopic level, empowering youths with an appreciation of plants and the importance of plant research to humankind.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This two-year collaborative Plant Plasticity Project addressed the role of beneficial fungi that colonize roots of diverse species in the resilience to moderate drought, if any, in two major food crops: rice and tomato. The project goals were: 1) to advance tools and methods to facilitate spatial-temporal monitoring of plant-arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) interactions at the chromatin and mRNA levels;  2) to perform a high-resolution survey of AMF-root interactions at the cell-type level under well-irrigated growth conditions to begin to evaluate the impact of AMF-plant symbiosis on water deficit stress molecular signatures, stress physiology and productivity; 3) from these data, to begin to identify conserved gene circuitry associated with root cell-specific responses to drought and upon fungal colonization; and 4) to train the next generation of scientists and the public about pathways to more sustainable and climate resilient agriculture. 

With respect to our first goal, we developed gene constructs and plant lines for capture of cells involved in perception and functional interaction with AMF in the two target species. We collaborated to establish substrate and low phosphate nutrition parameters for reproducible fungal colonization of root systems under conditions appropriate for water deficit stress and meaningful molecular and physiological monitoring. For both species, we commenced generation of genotypes that should provide targeted access to either the nucleus or translated mRNAs of cells directly associated with AMF attraction, symbiosis establishment and function. For rice, we utilized plant lines and methodology for controlled drought analyses established in our prior NSF project to map out the spatial temporal responses of the plant to AMF interactions for a number of cell populations of roots. Translatome analyses uncovered responses to AMF in distinct cell-populations, including vascular tissues that had not been recorded in the past. We evaluated the interaction between AMF and moderate drought by transcriptome sequencing. Due to unavoidable variation in the proportion of the root system that is colonized, we decided to sample roots systems of individual pots. This allowed the degree of colonization to be compared to the drought response.  In tomato, samples for translatome sequencing were prepared by one collaborator and shared with another. Additionally, we implemented single cell RNA sequencing techniques to establish a foundational cell atlas for root-AMF and drought interaction analyses. The single cell transcriptome of roots cultivated under the control conditions was used to advance the role of deposition of suberin, an apoplastic diffusion barrier, on responses to drought, primarily using physiological measurements. In rice, comparative evaluation of translated mRNAs of numerous root cell populations under control and drought conditions identified suites of regulatory, biosynthetic, and deposition genes related to those of tomato. With respect to the third goal, we began targeted mutagenesis and gene engineering of related regulatory and enzyme genes in both crops for a coordinated cross-species analysis of the drought and fungal interaction in future studies. 

With respect to the fourth goal, we trained the next generation of scientists and informed the public of the significance of plant biology, climate change research, and beneficial plant-microbe interactions. Although limited by the pandemic, we interfaced with individuals with diverse education and culture backgrounds through talks to lay audiences interested in science, hands-on learning activities for K-6 schools, and on community college and university campuses. We contributed to an annual course on advanced plant methods. We used multimedia, on- and off-campus visitations, lab modules, and internships to educate and inspire others about plant biology, genomics, and agriculture. We ensured our protocols, software, data, genetic and workshop materials were released to the public. 

Two publications from this project were principal products of our prior collaborative award. Due to the large quantity of data and time required for biological validation, these publications were completed during this project. The resources generated include gene expression atlases for tomato and rice that are readily accessible to the public.

This dissection of plant - microbe (biotic) - abiotic (drought) environmental interactions begins to apply cell and system levels approaches to understand how plants function in a multifactorial environment. The research defines root gene expression using spatial, single cell and cell population analyses. The identification and subsequent dissection of the functions of identified gene candidates from this work should ultimately aid  breeding and engineering of crops with greater resilience of water extremes and skills in nutrient acquisition. This project contributes to technology development and resources relevant to study of plants and other organisms.
